body:
Actually, although NUnit passes arguments as objects it doesn't simply call methods on Object in the implementation. We are able to examine the actual type of the objects passed and either cast it (if it's a well-known type) or use reflection. We currently use reflection to solve this problem as shown in my much earlier comment. We are apparently not doing a good enough job in complex cases.

So, in principal, it's possible to resolve this. Whether we want to give it priority and how much time we have and when we will fix it are separate questions. :-)

In my test, class **public class ObjectEquatable : IObjectEquatable1, IObjectEquatable2** implements 2 interfaces `IEquatable<IObjectEquatable1>` and `IEquatable<IObjectEquatable2>` with 2 methods **bool Equals(IObjectEquatable1 other)** and **bool Equals(IObjectEquatable2 other)**.

In the case, how nunit can select what **Equals** to call?

You may be right. I would have to spend some time to know for sure and I don't have it right now. :-(

Just off the top of my head, I believe the current code only handles situations where one object implements IObjectEquatable<T> with T being the exact type of the other object. We would have to recurse to all implemented interfaces for your example to work.

rename.from: CollectionAssert.AreEqual may not be properly comparing collections.
rename.to: NUnitEqualityComparer fails to compare IEquatable<T> where second object is derived from T

body: I have renamed this issue based on the fact that it has nothing to do with CollectionAssert, it is comparing an IEquatable<T> where the T being compared is derived from T.

issue.title: Allow NUnitComparer to compare IEquatable<T> where the second object is derived from T
issue.body:
Fixes #275 

Hopefully the unit tests speak for themselves :smile: 

We were using the T from an `IEquatable<T>`, which did not work if the second object was derived from T. I changed our logic to use `IsAssignableFrom`
